com.googlecode.gwt.charts.client.controls

Class ControlWrapperObject<O extends ControlOptions<?>,S extends ControlState>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.google.gwt.core.client.JavaScriptObject
      • com.googlecode.gwt.charts.client.HasListeners
        • com.googlecode.gwt.charts.client.controls.ControlWrapperObject<O,S>
  • Type Parameters:
    O - the options type for this control
    S - the state type for this control

    public class ControlWrapperObject<O extends ControlOptions<?>,S extends ControlState>
extends HasListeners
    A ControlWrapper object is a wrapper around a JSON representation of a configured control instance.
    The class exposes convenience methods for defining a dashboard control, drawing it and programmatically changing its state.
    See Also:
    Control Wrapper

      • create

        public static <O extends ControlOptions<?>,S extends ControlState> ControlWrapperObject<O,S> create()
        Creates an empty control wrapper. You must set all the appropriate properties using the set... methods.
        Type Parameters:
        O - the options type for this control
        S - the state type for this control
        Returns:
        an empty control wrapper

        Creates a control wrapper with the given specification.
        Type Parameters:
        O - the options type for this control
        S - the state type for this control
        Parameters:

      • addErrorHandler

        public final HandlerRef addErrorHandler(ErrorHandler handler)
        Fired when an error occurs when attempting to render the control.
        Parameters:
        handler - the error handler
        Returns:
        a reference for removing this handler

      • addReadyHandler

        public final HandlerRef addReadyHandler(ReadyHandler handler)
        The control is ready to accept user interaction and for external method calls. If you want to interact with the control, and call methods after you draw it, you should set up a listener for this event before you call the draw method, and call them only after the event was fired. Alternatively, you can listen for a ready event on the dashboard holding the control and call control methods only after the event was fired.
        Parameters:
        handler - the ready handler
        Returns:
        a reference for removing this handler

      • addStateChangeHandler

        public final HandlerRef addStateChangeHandler(StateChangeHandler handler)
        Fired when the user interacts with the control, affecting its state. For example, a statechange event will fire whenever you move the thumbs of a range slider control. To retrieve an updated control state after the event fired, call ControlWrapper.getState().
        Parameters:
        handler - the state change handler
        Returns:
        a reference for removing this handler

      • cloneObject

        public final ControlWrapperObject<O,S> cloneObject()
        Returns a deep copy of the control wrapper.
        Returns:
        a deep copy of the control wrapper

      • draw

        public final void draw()
        Draws the control. Normally the dashboard holding the control takes care of drawing it. You should call draw() to force programmatic redraws of the control after you change any of its other settings, like options or state.

      • getContainerId

        public final String getContainerId()
        The ID of the control's DOM container element.
        Returns:
        container element ID

      • getControl

        public final Control getControl()
        Returns a reference to the control created by this ControlWrapper. This will return null until after you have called draw() on the ControlWrapper object (or on the dashboard holding it), and it throws a ready event. The returned object only exposes one method: resetControl(), which resets the control state to the one it was initialized with (like resetting an HTML form element).
        Returns:
        a reference to the control created by this ControlWrapper.

      • getControlName

        public final String getControlName()
        Returns the control name assigned by setControlName().
        Returns:
        control name

      • getControlType

        public final String getControlType()
        The class name of the control. If this is a Google control, the name will not be qualified with google.visualization. So, for example, if this were a CategoryFilter control, it would return "CategoryFilter" rather than "google.visualization.CategoryFilter".
        Returns:
        the class name of the control.

      • getOption

        public final String getOption(String key)
        Returns the specified control option value.
        Parameters:
        key - the name of the option to retrieve. May be a qualified name, such as 'vAxis.title'.
        Returns:
        control option value

      • getOption

        public final String getOption(String key,
               String defaultValue)
        Returns the specified control option value. If the value is undefined or null, the specified default value will be returned.
        Parameters:
        key - the name of the option to retrieve. May be a qualified name, such as 'vAxis.title'.
        defaultValue - If the specified value is undefined or null, this value will be returned.
        Returns:
        control option value or default value

      • getOptions

        public final O getOptions()
        Returns the options object for this control.
        Returns:
        the options object for this control

      • getState

        public final S getState()
        Returns the control state.
        Returns:
        the control state

      • setContainerId

        public final void setContainerId(String containerId)
        Sets the ID of the containing DOM element for the control.
        Parameters:
        containerId - the ID of the containing DOM element

      • setControlName

        public final void setControlName(String controlName)
        Sets an arbitrary name for the control. This is not shown anywhere on the control, but is for your reference only.
        Parameters:
        controlName - an arbitrary name for the control

      • setControlType

        public final void setControlType(ControlType controlType)
        Sets the control type. Pass in the class name of the control to instantiate. If this is a Google control, do not qualify it with google.visualization. So, for example, for a range slider over a numeric column, pass in "NumberRangeFilter".
        Parameters:
        controlType - the control type

      • setOption

        public final void setOption(String key,
             String value)
        Sets a single control option value, where key is the option name and value is the value. To unset an option, pass in null for the value. Note that key may be a qualified name, such as 'vAxis.title'
        Parameters:
        key - the option name
        value - the value

      • setOptions

        public final void setOptions(O options)
        Sets a complete options object for a control.
        Parameters:
        options - a complete options object

      • setState

        public final void setState(S state)
        Sets the control state. The state collects all the variables that the user operating the control can affect. For example, a range slider state can be described in term of the positions that the low and high thumb of the slider occupy.
        Parameters:
        state - the control state

      • toJSON

        public final String toJSON()
        Returns a string version of the JSON representation of the control.
        Returns:
        JSON representation of the control
